title: DOGE Analysis: £3.4M in Duplicates, £1.1M to Non-Compliant Suppliers, and a 12.9x Year-End Spike
summary: Our comprehensive DOGE-style audit of 29,802 spending records totalling £211 million has uncovered duplicate payments, Companies House compliance failures, and the worst year-end spending surge in East Lancashire.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: £1.1 Million Paid to Suppliers With No Active Directors at Companies House
summary: Hyndburn paid £420,200 to B3P Services Ltd while it had no active directors — and £1.1 million in total to 17 suppliers during active Companies House breaches. Some had no directors AND no person with significant control.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: £3.4 Million in Likely Duplicate Payments Across 940 Groups
summary: Analysis of Hyndburn's spending data reveals 940 duplicate payment groups totalling £3.4 million — the highest value of any East Lancashire council. HM Land Registry alone has 2,422 tiny transactions averaging £5 each.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: 12.9x Year-End Spending Spike: The Worst in East Lancashire
summary: Hyndburn's Regeneration & Housing department spent 12.9 times its monthly average in March — £3.7 million above normal. This is the worst year-end spending surge of any department across Hyndburn, Burnley, and Pendle.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: Cross-Council Comparison: 37 Shared Suppliers and a 115,237% Price Gap
summary: Hyndburn shares 37 suppliers with Burnley and Pendle, with combined spending of £28.1 million. Price comparisons reveal extreme variations — one supplier charges Burnley 115,237% more than Pendle for equivalent services.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: Three Years Without Clean Audit: Hyndburn's Financial Black Hole
summary: Hyndburn's accounts for 2022/23 and 2023/24 both received a disclaimer of opinion — the most serious audit outcome possible. The auditor could not confirm if £211M of public spending is correct, and the month with the most suspicious spending falls within these unverifiable accounts.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: Hyndburn Leisure Trust: £1 Million Per Year Subsidy and a £12M Capital Ask
summary: The leisure trust has reportedly lost money every year since formation, costing taxpayers ~£1M annually. Now it is requesting £12M for Wilson's Playing Field — bringing the estimated total cost to over £22M. Is the trust model delivering value?
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: The Exempt Accommodation Problem: Hyndburn's £1M Annual Housing Benefit Black Hole
summary: Supported Exempt Accommodation providers claim enhanced Housing Benefit for minimal 'support', costing Hyndburn ~£1M per year in subsidy losses. Many providers are not registered charities despite claiming charitable purposes — and the council bears the cost.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: Hyndburn's Reserves in Freefall: £30M to £12M in One Year
summary: Hyndburn's usable reserves reportedly collapsed from approximately £30 million to £12 million in a single financial year — an unprecedented 60% drawdown that raises fundamental questions about financial management under Cllr Miles Parkinson's centralised leadership.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: In-House vs Outsourced: How Hyndburn's Service Delivery Model Compares
summary: Hyndburn runs most services in-house with ~137 staff, while Burnley and Pendle outsource to Liberata. Without benchmarking data, there is no way to prove whether Hyndburn's model delivers value — making 'in-house' a political preference rather than an evidence-based decision.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: Accrington Town Square: The £60-70M Question
summary: Morgan Sindall's regeneration contract for Accrington town centre is stated at between £60M and £70M depending on the source — a £10M discrepancy for Hyndburn's largest ever capital programme. Initiated under Parkinson's centralised leadership, the project is reportedly behind schedule.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: Hyndburn's Waste Crisis: No Transfer Station, No Plan
summary: With Whinney Hill landfill closing and a food waste collection mandate approaching, Hyndburn reportedly has not secured a waste transfer station for April 2026. Estimated additional costs of £720K-£1.3M per year for a council already stretched to breaking point.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: Huncoat Garden Village: A £463M Bet by a £17M Council
summary: The Huncoat Garden Village housing development has a total value of ~£463M — roughly 27 times Hyndburn's annual budget. With contaminated land, infrastructure costs, and governance questions, this mega-project demands institutional capacity that Parkinson's centralised model did not build.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: Lancashire's Liberata Problem: £90M+ to One Company Across Two Councils
summary: Liberata UK Ltd has received over £90M combined from Burnley and Pendle councils for outsourced services. Burnley is ending its contract and bringing services in-house from 2026, yet Pendle's £54M contract continues — at £591 per resident, more than four times what Hyndburn spends delivering equivalent services in-house.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: The LGR Endgame: What Happens to Debts, Contracts, and Reserves When Councils Merge
summary: Lancashire's Local Government Reorganisation will merge 12 district councils into new unitary authorities. But who inherits Burnley's £80M+ commercial property debt, Pendle's £54M Liberata contract, and Hyndburn's depleted reserves? Lessons from Northamptonshire, Cumbria, and Somerset suggest transition costs are always higher than promised.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency

title: Waste Disposal: Lancashire's Shared Crisis
summary: All three East Lancashire councils face a simultaneous waste crisis: Whinney Hill landfill has closed, the food waste collection mandate requires new infrastructure, and LCC is restructuring disposal arrangements. Combined additional costs could exceed £8-10M per year across the three boroughs — with Hyndburn reportedly lacking a waste transfer station entirely.
author: Hyndburn Council Transparency
